gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)

header: 1% of peak computational performance is used (0.75 out of 64.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
43% of SSE/AVX instructions are used in vector version (process two or more data elements in vector registers):
  • 0% of SSE/AVX loads are used in vector version.
  • 25% of SSE/AVX addition or subtraction instructions are used in vector version.
  • 54% of SSE/AVX instructions that are not load, store, addition, subtraction nor multiply instructions are used in vector version.
Since your execution units are vector units, only a fully vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is poorly vectorized.
Only 16% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By fully vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 8.00 to 0.77 cycles (10.38x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.

header:
The loop is defined in /home/mathieu/Downloads/AOA-Project5/mathieu_icx/../src/kernel.c:51-58. Analyzed code is defined in /home/mathieu/Downloads/AOA-Project5/mathieu_icx/../src/kernel.c:51,56-58. Warnings: Non-innermost loop: analyzing only self part (ignoring child loops). This loop has 3 execution paths. The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck. Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):
  • hoisting them (moving them outside the loop)
  • turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX
Ex: if (x<0) x=0 => x = (x<0 ? 0 : x) (or MAX(0,x) after defining the corresponding macro)
